words.definition: The scientific study of the mind and how it affects behavior.
sentences: Psychology helps us understand why people act the way they do.
She is studying psychology at university.
Learning about psychology can help you understand yourself better.

words.definition: The way a person or animal acts or conducts themselves.
sentences: Good behavior is important in school.
The dog's behavior changed after training.
His behavior showed he was upset.

words.definition: The part of a person that thinks, feels, and imagines.
sentences: Keep an open mind when learning new things.
She has a very creative mind.
Your mind is very powerful.

words.definition: A strong feeling such as joy, sadness, anger, or fear.
sentences: Happiness is a positive emotion.
He showed a lot of emotion during the sad movie.
It's important to understand your emotions.

words.definition: An emotional state or reaction.
sentences: I have a good feeling about this test.
She shared her feelings with her friend.
It's normal to have mixed feelings sometimes.

words.definition: An idea or opinion produced by thinking.
sentences: He shared his thoughts on the topic.
She had a sudden thought about what to do.
Keep your thoughts positive.

words.definition: The ability to remember things, or a specific thing remembered.
sentences: I have a good memory for faces.
That vacation is a happy memory.
She tried to recall the memory of the event.

words.definition: The process of gaining knowledge or skill.
sentences: Learning a new language takes time.
She enjoys the process of learning.
Online courses make learning easier.

words.definition: The way we understand or interpret something using our senses.
sentences: His perception of the situation was different from mine.
Our five senses help our perception of the world.
First impressions often shape our perception.

words.definition: The reason or reasons one has for acting or behaving in a particular way.
sentences: His motivation to succeed was very strong.
What is your motivation for studying hard?
Lack of motivation can make tasks difficult.

words.definition: The combination of characteristics or qualities that form an individual's distinct character.
sentences: She has a very friendly personality.
His personality makes him a good leader.
Everyone has a unique personality.

words.definition: The process of growing or changing over time.
sentences: Child development is a key area in psychology.
Reading helps with language development.
The city is undergoing rapid development.

words.definition: Relating to society or the way people interact with each other.
sentences: Humans are social beings.
She enjoys social gatherings with friends.
Social skills are important for teamwork.

words.definition: The mental processes of acquiring knowledge and understanding through thought, experience, and the senses.
sentences: Memory and problem-solving are parts of cognition.
The test measured his cognitive abilities.
Cognition helps us make sense of the world.

words.definition: The state of being aware of one's own existence and surroundings.
sentences: He lost consciousness after the fall.
Dreams occur when we are not fully in consciousness.
The patient slowly regained consciousness.

words.definition: The part of the mind of which one is not fully aware but which influences one's actions and feelings.
sentences: Sometimes our subconscious thoughts affect our decisions.
Dreams can reveal things from our subconscious mind.
He had a subconscious fear of heights.

words.definition: Not awake and aware of surroundings; or, the part of the mind containing feelings and thoughts that are not conscious.
sentences: He was unconscious after hitting his head.
Freud studied the influence of the unconscious mind.
Sometimes unconscious biases affect our judgment.

words.definition: An inborn pattern of behavior that is typical of a species.
sentences: Birds build nests by instinct.
My first instinct was to run away.
Survival instinct is very strong.

words.definition: A regular tendency or practice, especially one that is hard to give up.
sentences: Brushing your teeth every morning is a good habit.
He has a habit of biting his nails.
Breaking a bad habit can be challenging.

words.definition: A distinguishing quality or characteristic, typically one belonging to a person.
sentences: Kindness is a positive personality trait.
He has many good traits.
Honesty is an important trait to have.

words.definition: A person's or animal's nature, especially as it permanently affects their behavior.
sentences: She has a calm temperament.
His artistic temperament makes him very creative.
Children often have different temperaments.

words.definition: A temporary state of mind or feeling.
sentences: She was in a good mood today.
His bad mood affected everyone.
Music can change your mood.

words.definition: A state of mental or emotional strain or tension resulting from adverse or demanding circumstances.
sentences: Exams can cause a lot of stress.
He feels stress when he has too much work.
Exercise can help reduce stress.

words.definition: A feeling of worry, nervousness, or unease, typically about an event or something with an uncertain outcome.
sentences: She felt anxiety before her big presentation.
Anxiety can make it hard to sleep.
Deep breathing can help calm anxiety.

words.definition: A state of low mood and aversion to activity that can affect a person's thoughts, behavior, feelings, and sense of well-being.
sentences: Talking to someone can help with depression.
Depression is a serious mental health condition.
Support groups offer help for people with depression.

words.definition: Treatment intended to heal or relieve a disorder.
sentences: She started therapy to help with her anxiety.
Talking therapy can be very helpful.
Physical therapy helps people recover from injuries.

words.definition: The provision of professional assistance and guidance in resolving personal or psychological problems.
sentences: He received counseling to cope with his grief.
School counselors offer guidance to students.
Counseling can help you find solutions to problems.

words.definition: A professional who studies the mind and behavior.
sentences: The psychologist helped him understand his feelings.
She consulted a child psychologist about her son's behavior.
Psychologists conduct research and provide therapy.

words.definition: A medical doctor who specializes in mental health, including substance use disorders.
sentences: The psychiatrist prescribed medication for her anxiety.
Psychiatrists can diagnose and treat mental illnesses.
He sees a psychiatrist for his mental health.

words.definition: A person's emotional, psychological, and social well-being.
sentences: Taking care of your mental health is as important as physical health.
Many organizations promote mental health awareness.
Talking about your feelings can improve your mental health.

words.definition: The state of being comfortable, healthy, or happy.
sentences: Exercise contributes to overall well-being.
She cares deeply about her family's well-being.
Mental well-being is crucial for a fulfilling life.

words.definition: Confidence in one's own worth or abilities; self-respect.
sentences: Building self-esteem is important for teenagers.
Positive feedback can boost self-esteem.
Low self-esteem can affect a person's confidence.

words.definition: The feeling or belief that one can rely on someone or something; firm trust.
sentences: She spoke with great confidence during her presentation.
His confidence grew with practice.
Confidence is key to achieving your goals.

words.definition: The ability to understand and share the feelings of another.
sentences: Showing empathy helps build strong friendships.
She has a lot of empathy for others.
Empathy is an important quality for a good listener.

words.definition: Feelings of pity and sorrow for someone else's misfortune.
sentences: I felt great sympathy for the lost child.
She offered her sympathy to her grieving friend.
He expressed his sympathy for their loss.

words.definition: The belief in or practice of selfless concern for the well-being of others.
sentences: His act of kindness was a true example of altruism.
Altruism is a valuable human quality.
Many charities are built on the principle of altruism.

words.definition: Hostile or violent behavior or attitudes toward another; readiness to attack or confront.
sentences: The dog showed signs of aggression.
Aggression can be a response to fear.
It's important to manage aggression in a healthy way.

words.definition: The process of working together to achieve the same goal.
sentences: Teamwork requires good cooperation.
International cooperation is needed to solve global problems.
Children learn cooperation through games.

words.definition: A serious disagreement or argument.
sentences: They had a conflict over who would use the computer.
Learning to resolve conflict is a valuable skill.
The story involved a major conflict between two families.

words.definition: The act of finding a solution to a problem or conflict.
sentences: They worked towards a peaceful resolution of the conflict.
The new year is a time for making resolutions.
The conflict reached a quick resolution.

words.definition: The process of sharing information, ideas, or feelings.
sentences: Good communication is key in any relationship.
She has excellent communication skills.
Effective communication prevents misunderstandings.

words.definition: Not involving words or speech.
sentences: Body language is a form of nonverbal communication.
His nonverbal cues showed he was nervous.
We often communicate nonverbally without realizing it.

words.definition: Relating to or in the form of words.
sentences: She gave a verbal agreement to the plan.
Verbal communication is important in a classroom.
His verbal skills are very strong.

words.definition: The act of paying attention to sound.
sentences: Active listening is important for understanding others.
Good listening skills are valuable in any job.
She practiced listening to her friends without interrupting.

words.definition: The action or process of observing something carefully in order to gain information.
sentences: Scientists make careful observations during experiments.
Her keen observation helped solve the puzzle.
Psychologists rely on observation of behavior.

words.definition: A scientific procedure undertaken to make a discovery, test a hypothesis, or demonstrate a known fact.
sentences: The students conducted a science experiment.
Psychologists often use experiments to study behavior.
The results of the experiment were surprising.

words.definition: A proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation.
sentences: The scientist formed a hypothesis about how the brain works.
Her hypothesis was tested in the experiment.
A good hypothesis can be proven wrong.

words.definition: A system of ideas intended to explain something, especially one based on general principles independent of the thing to be explained.
sentences: Einstein developed the theory of relativity.
Psychologists have many theories about human behavior.
The new theory explains the phenomenon well.

words.definition: The systematic investigation into and study of materials and sources in order to establish facts and reach new conclusions.
sentences: She is doing research for her school project.
Psychological research helps us understand the mind.
The new research provided important findings.

words.definition: Facts and statistics collected together for reference or analysis.
sentences: The scientists collected a lot of data.
Analyze the data to find patterns.
The survey provided interesting data about opinions.

words.definition: Detailed examination of the elements or structure of something.
sentences: The psychologist performed an analysis of his patient's dreams.
Data analysis is an important part of research.
Her analysis of the problem was very insightful.

words.definition: The end or finish of an event or process, or a judgment or decision reached by reasoning.
sentences: The experiment led to an important conclusion.
What conclusion did you draw from the evidence?
The book's conclusion was very satisfying.

words.definition: Moral principles that govern a person's behavior or the conducting of an activity.
sentences: Scientists must follow strict ethics in their research.
It's important to have good work ethics.
The discussion covered the ethics of artificial intelligence.

words.definition: The state of keeping or being kept secret or private.
sentences: Therapists must maintain patient confidentiality.
All personal information is treated with strict confidentiality.
He assured her of complete confidentiality.

words.definition: The state of being free from public attention.
sentences: Everyone deserves a right to privacy.
She values her privacy very much.
The law protects personal privacy.

words.definition: Permission for something to happen or agreement to do something.
sentences: You need parental consent to go on the trip.
He gave his consent for the medical procedure.
Research participants must give informed consent.

words.definition: Prejudice in favor of or against one thing, person, or group compared with another, usually in a way considered to be unfair.
sentences: Try to avoid bias when making decisions.
The news report showed a clear bias.
Everyone can have unconscious biases.

words.definition: A widely held but fixed and oversimplified image or idea of a particular type of person or thing.
sentences: It's wrong to judge people based on stereotypes.
The movie challenged common stereotypes.
Avoid using stereotypes in your language.

words.definition: Preconceived opinion that is not based on reason or actual experience.
sentences: Prejudice can lead to unfair treatment.
He fought against racial prejudice.
Education can help reduce prejudice.

words.definition: The unjust or prejudicial treatment of different categories of people or things, especially on the grounds of race, age, or sex.
sentences: Discrimination in the workplace is illegal.
She experienced discrimination because of her age.
Fighting discrimination is important for equality.

words.definition: The state of being equal, especially in status, rights, or opportunities.
sentences: Everyone should have equality of opportunity.
The movement fought for gender equality.
Equality means treating everyone fairly.

words.definition: The state of being diverse; variety.
sentences: Diversity in a team brings different ideas.
The school celebrates cultural diversity.
Diversity makes our world richer.

words.definition: The practice or policy of providing equal access to opportunities and resources for people who might otherwise be excluded or marginalized.
sentences: Inclusion ensures everyone feels welcome.
The company promotes diversity and inclusion.
Inclusion in education benefits all students.

words.definition: A cognitive bias that makes it difficult for a person to understand or feel what another person is experiencing.
sentences: Sometimes an empathy gap makes it hard to relate to others' pain.
Bridging the empathy gap can improve relationships.
The empathy gap can lead to misunderstandings.

words.definition: A systematic error in thinking that affects the decisions and judgments that people make.
sentences: Confirmation bias is a common cognitive bias.
Understanding cognitive biases can improve decision-making.
Cognitive biases can lead to irrational choices.

words.definition: The tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information in a way that confirms one's preexisting beliefs or hypotheses.
sentences: Confirmation bias can make it hard to change your mind.
Be aware of confirmation bias when researching a topic.
Confirmation bias strengthens existing beliefs.

words.definition: A cognitive bias in which an observer's overall impression of a person, company, brand, or product influences the observer's feelings and thoughts about that entity's character or properties.
sentences: The halo effect made him seem more intelligent than he was.
Celebrities often benefit from the halo effect.
The halo effect can influence first impressions.

words.definition: A beneficial effect produced by a placebo drug or treatment, which cannot be attributed to the properties of the placebo itself, and must therefore be due to the patient's belief in that treatment.
sentences: The placebo effect shows the power of the mind.
Some studies show a strong placebo effect.
The patient felt better due to the placebo effect.

words.definition: A prediction that directly or indirectly causes itself to become true, by the very fact that the prophecy has been made.
sentences: Her negative attitude became a self-fulfilling prophecy.
Believe in yourself to avoid a negative self-fulfilling prophecy.
The teacher's expectation created a self-fulfilling prophecy for the student.

words.definition: The state of having inconsistent thoughts, beliefs, or attitudes, especially as relating to behavioral decisions and attitude change.
sentences: He felt cognitive dissonance when his actions didn't match his beliefs.
Cognitive dissonance can be uncomfortable.
People try to reduce cognitive dissonance.

words.definition: The process of training or accustoming someone or something to behave in a certain way or to accept certain circumstances.
sentences: Pavlov's experiments showed classical conditioning in dogs.
Behavioral conditioning can help change habits.
He used positive conditioning to train his pet.

words.definition: The process of encouraging or establishing a belief or pattern of behavior.
sentences: Positive reinforcement helps children learn faster.
The reward served as a reinforcement for good behavior.
Lack of reinforcement can lead to a behavior fading.

words.definition: The infliction or imposition of a penalty as retribution for an offense.
sentences: Punishment can sometimes change behavior.
The punishment for cheating was severe.
Parents sometimes use punishment to teach lessons.

words.definition: Learning by observing others.
sentences: Children often learn through observational learning.
Observational learning is a powerful way to acquire new skills.
He improved his technique through observational learning.

words.definition: Learning by imitating others' behavior.
sentences: Parents are important role models for their children's behavior modeling.
He learned the dance steps through modeling.
Modeling good behavior is important.

words.definition: The unwritten rules of behavior that are considered acceptable in a group or society.
sentences: Following social norms helps us fit in.
Social norms can vary greatly between cultures.
Breaking social norms can sometimes lead to change.

words.definition: The practice of thinking or making decisions as a group in a way that discourages creativity or individual responsibility.
sentences: Groupthink can lead to bad decisions in a team.
Avoid groupthink to encourage diverse opinions.
The committee fell victim to groupthink.

words.definition: Behavior in accordance with socially accepted conventions or standards.
sentences: Peer pressure can lead to conformity.
Conformity is sometimes necessary for social order.
She resisted conformity and chose her own path.

words.definition: Compliance with an order, request, or law or submission to another's authority.
sentences: Dogs are trained for obedience.
Obedience to rules keeps everyone safe.
The soldiers showed strict obedience to their commander.

words.definition: The power or right to give orders, make decisions, and enforce obedience.
sentences: The teacher has authority in the classroom.
He spoke with authority on the subject.
Respecting authority is important.

words.definition: A settled way of thinking or feeling about something.
sentences: She has a positive attitude towards life.
His bad attitude affected his performance.
Your attitude can influence your success.

words.definition: An acceptance that a statement is true or that something exists.
sentences: He has a strong belief in honesty.
Religious belief is important to many people.
Her belief in herself helped her achieve her goals.

words.definition: The regard that something is held to deserve; the importance, worth, or usefulness of something.
sentences: Honesty is a core value in our family.
She places a high value on education.
Different cultures have different values.

words.definition: A standard or pattern, especially of social behavior, that is typical or expected of a group.
sentences: It is the norm to shake hands when meeting someone new.
Social norms guide our interactions.
Breaking the norm can be challenging.

words.definition: The function assumed or part played by a person or thing in a particular situation.
sentences: He played an important role in the team.
What is your role in this project?
Parents play a crucial role in their children's lives.

words.definition: The fact of being who or what a person or thing is.
sentences: She has a strong sense of her cultural identity.
Teenagers often explore their identity.
His identity was linked to his profession.

words.definition: An individual's belief about himself or herself, including the person's attributes and who and what the self is.
sentences: A positive self-concept is important for mental health.
His self-concept was shaped by his experiences.
Developing a healthy self-concept takes time.

words.definition: Conscious knowledge of one's own character, feelings, motives, and desires.
sentences: Self-awareness is the first step to personal growth.
Meditation can increase self-awareness.
She gained self-awareness through therapy.

words.definition: The ability to control one's own behavior, emotions, and thoughts.
sentences: Children learn self-regulation as they grow.
Good self-regulation helps in managing stress.
Self-regulation is key to achieving long-term goals.

words.definition: A strategy used to deal with a difficult situation.
sentences: Exercise is a healthy coping mechanism for stress.
Everyone has different coping mechanisms.
Talking to a friend can be a good coping mechanism.

words.definition: The capacity to recover quickly from difficulties; toughness.
sentences: She showed great resilience after facing challenges.
Building resilience helps you bounce back from setbacks.
Resilience is an important quality for overcoming adversity.

words.definition: The process of changing to suit different conditions.
sentences: Humans have a great capacity for adaptation.
Adaptation to a new environment can be challenging.
Psychology studies how people achieve adaptation.

words.definition: The construction of thought processes, including remembering, problem-solving, and decision-making, from childhood through adolescence to adulthood.
sentences: Play is important for a child's cognitive development.
The theory explains stages of cognitive development.
Cognitive development continues throughout life.

words.definition: The capacity to be aware of, control, and express one's emotions, and to handle interpersonal relationships judiciously and empathetically.
sentences: Emotional intelligence is important for leadership.
She has high emotional intelligence.
Developing emotional intelligence helps in social situations.

words.definition: The process of learning to behave in a way that is acceptable to society.
sentences: School plays a role in a child's socialization.
Socialization helps people understand cultural norms.
Pets also go through a process of socialization.

words.definition: A strong emotional bond or affection.
sentences: Babies form strong attachments to their caregivers.
She has a deep attachment to her childhood home.
Secure attachment is important for healthy development.

words.definition: Relating to relationships or communication between people.
sentences: Good interpersonal skills are important for teamwork.
He struggles with interpersonal communication.
Interpersonal relationships are a key area of study in psychology.

words.definition: The interactions and relationships between members of a group.
sentences: Understanding group dynamics helps improve team performance.
The workshop focused on positive group dynamics.
Group dynamics can influence individual behavior.

words.definition: The action of leading a group of people or an organization.
sentences: Good leadership is essential for a successful team.
She showed strong leadership qualities.
Leadership involves guiding and motivating others.

words.definition: A theory that explains why people are motivated to do things.
sentences: Maslow's hierarchy of needs is a famous motivation theory.
Understanding motivation theory can help in managing employees.
Different motivation theories offer various perspectives.

words.definition: A type of psychotherapy in which negative patterns of thought about the self and the world are challenged in order to alter unwanted behavior patterns.
sentences: Cognitive therapy helps people change negative thinking.
She found cognitive therapy very effective for her anxiety.
Cognitive therapy focuses on current problems.

words.definition: A type of therapy that aims to help a person change potentially self-destructive behaviors.
sentences: Behavioral therapy can help treat phobias.
He underwent behavioral therapy to overcome his fear.
Behavioral therapy focuses on changing actions.

words.definition: Relating to the interaction of conscious and unconscious mental or emotional processes.
sentences: Psychodynamic therapy explores past experiences.
Freud's theories are psychodynamic.
Psychodynamic approaches look at deep-seated issues.

words.definition: Relating to an approach that emphasizes human potential and self-actualization.
sentences: Humanistic psychology focuses on personal growth.
Carl Rogers was a key figure in humanistic therapy.
The humanistic approach values individual experience.

words.definition: The scientific study of the nervous system, including the brain.
sentences: Neuroscience helps us understand how the brain works.
She is passionate about neuroscience research.
Advances in neuroscience have revealed much about the mind.

words.definition: An organ of soft nervous tissue contained in the skull, functioning as the coordinating center of sensation and intellectual and nervous activity.
sentences: The human brain is incredibly complex.
Learning new things helps your brain grow.
The brain controls all our thoughts and actions.

words.definition: The network of nerve cells and fibers that transmits nerve impulses between parts of the body.
sentences: The nervous system controls our senses and movements.
Stress can affect the nervous system.
The brain is part of the central nervous system.

words.definition: Chemical substances produced in the body that control many body functions.
sentences: Hormones play a role in mood and growth.
Stress hormones can affect your health.
The body's hormones regulate various processes.

words.definition: The study of heredity and the variation of inherited characteristics.
sentences: Genetics plays a role in our personality traits.
Scientists study genetics to understand diseases.
Our genetics influence many aspects of our lives.

words.definition: The passing on of physical or mental characteristics from one generation to another.
sentences: Eye color is determined by heredity.
Heredity plays a role in some behaviors.
Understanding heredity helps explain family traits.

words.definition: The surroundings or conditions in which a person, animal, or plant lives or operates.
sentences: Our environment can influence our behavior.
A supportive environment helps children thrive.
Protecting the natural environment is important.

words.definition: A debate about whether human behavior is determined by genes (nature) or by environment (nurture).
sentences: The nature vs. nurture debate is central to psychology.
Some traits are clearly influenced by both nature and nurture.
The question of nature vs. nurture is complex.

words.definition: The study of mental processes such as attention, language use, memory, perception, problem-solving, and thinking.
sentences: Cognitive psychology helps us understand how we think.
She specializes in cognitive psychology.
Research in cognitive psychology has improved education.

words.definition: The scientific study of how and why human beings change over the course of their life.
sentences: Developmental psychology covers changes from birth to old age.
He is interested in child developmental psychology.
Developmental psychology examines growth and learning.

words.definition: The study of how people's thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are influenced by the actual, imagined, or implied presence of others.
sentences: Social psychology explains group behavior.
She took a course on social psychology.
Social psychology helps understand human interaction.

words.definition: The branch of psychology concerned with the assessment and treatment of mental illness and disability.
sentences: Clinical psychology focuses on helping people with mental health issues.
He works as a clinical psychologist.
Clinical psychology involves therapy and diagnosis.

words.definition: The study of abnormal behavior and mental illness.
sentences: Abnormal psychology explores different mental disorders.
She finds abnormal psychology very interesting.
Understanding abnormal psychology helps in treatment.

words.definition: The study of psychological and behavioral processes in health, illness, and healthcare.
sentences: Health psychology examines the link between mind and body.
She works in health psychology, promoting well-being.
Health psychology helps people cope with chronic illness.

words.definition: The study of how humans learn in educational settings, the effectiveness of educational interventions, the psychology of teaching, and the social psychology of schools.
sentences: Educational psychology helps improve teaching methods.
She is an educational psychologist.
Educational psychology focuses on learning and development in schools.

words.definition: The application of psychological principles and research methods to legal issues.
sentences: Forensic psychology is used in criminal investigations.
He is interested in a career in forensic psychology.
Forensic psychology helps understand criminal behavior.

words.definition: The study of how psychological factors affect performance and how participation in sport and exercise affect psychological and physical factors.
sentences: Sports psychology helps athletes improve their mental game.
She consults a sports psychologist.
Sports psychology focuses on motivation and focus.

words.definition: The scientific study of human behavior in the workplace and applies psychological principles to workplace issues.
sentences: Industrial-organizational psychology helps improve employee satisfaction.
She works in industrial-organizational psychology.
This field focuses on productivity and workplace dynamics.

words.definition: The scientific study of what makes life most worth living, focusing on strengths and virtues.
sentences: Positive psychology emphasizes happiness and well-being.
She practices principles of positive psychology.
Positive psychology helps people flourish.

words.definition: A common type of talk therapy that helps you become aware of inaccurate or negative thinking so you can view challenging situations more clearly and respond to them in a more effective way.
sentences: CBT is often used to treat anxiety and depression.
She learned coping skills through CBT.
CBT helps change negative thought patterns.

words.definition: The quality or state of being conscious or aware of something.
sentences: Practicing mindfulness can reduce stress.
Mindfulness meditation helps you focus on the present moment.
She tries to live with more mindfulness.

words.definition: The practice of focusing one's mind for a period of time, in silence or with the aid of chanting, for religious or spiritual purposes or as a method of relaxation.
sentences: Meditation can help improve focus and calm.
She practices meditation every morning.
Many people use meditation to relax.

words.definition: The state of being free from tension and anxiety.
sentences: Listening to music helps me with relaxation.
She enjoys relaxation after a long day.
Deep breathing is a good relaxation technique.

words.definition: Strategies used to deal with stress and difficult emotions.
sentences: Learning healthy coping skills is important for mental well-being.
She taught her children various coping skills.
Coping skills help manage challenging situations.

words.definition: The ability to respond to the ongoing demands of experience with the range of emotions in a manner that is socially tolerable and sufficiently flexible to permit spontaneous reactions as well as the ability to delay spontaneous reactions as needed.
sentences: Emotional regulation is a key part of emotional intelligence.
Children learn emotional regulation as they grow.
Improving emotional regulation can lead to better relationships.

words.definition: The process of finding solutions to difficult or complex issues.
sentences: Good problem-solving skills are valued in any job.
She is excellent at problem-solving.
We worked together on a problem-solving task.

words.definition: The action or process of making important decisions.
sentences: Effective decision-making requires careful thought.
He is good at quick decision-making.
Group decision-making can be challenging.

words.definition: The objective analysis and evaluation of an issue in order to form a judgment.
sentences: Critical thinking is essential for academic success.
She encourages critical thinking in her students.
Develop critical thinking to evaluate information.

words.definition: The use of imagination or original ideas to create something.
sentences: Her creativity shines in her artwork.
Creativity is important for innovation.
He uses his creativity to solve problems.

words.definition: The faculty or action of forming new ideas, or images or concepts of external objects not present to the senses.
sentences: Children have vivid imaginations.
Use your imagination to write a story.
Imagination is key to invention.

words.definition: The ability to understand concepts that are not concrete or directly observable.
sentences: Philosophy requires abstract thinking.
Abstract thinking develops as children grow.
Math problems often require abstract thinking.

words.definition: A literal form of thinking that focuses on facts and specific objects rather than ideas or concepts.
sentences: Young children often engage in concrete thinking.
Concrete thinking focuses on the here and now.
Some tasks require concrete thinking, others abstract.

words.definition: The action of thinking about something in a logical, sensible way.
sentences: His reasoning for the decision was sound.
Logical reasoning is important in problem-solving.
She used careful reasoning to reach her conclusion.

words.definition: Reasoning conducted or assessed according to strict principles of validity.
sentences: His argument was based on sound logic.
There is no logic in his actions.
She used logic to solve the puzzle.

words.definition: The ability to understand something immediately, without the need for conscious reasoning.
sentences: Sometimes you just have to trust your intuition.
Her intuition told her something was wrong.
Intuition can be a powerful guide.

words.definition: The capacity to gain an accurate and deep understanding of someone or something.
sentences: The book provided great insight into human behavior.
He had a sudden insight into the problem.
Therapy can help you gain self-insight.

words.definition: Knowledge or perception of a situation or fact.
sentences: Public awareness of mental health issues is growing.
She has a strong awareness of her surroundings.
Awareness is the first step to change.

words.definition: The act or power of fixing the mind on something.
sentences: Pay attention to the teacher.
He has a short attention span.
Her attention was drawn to the loud noise.

words.definition: The action or power of focusing one's attention or mental effort.
sentences: It takes good concentration to solve complex problems.
She lost her concentration during the exam.
Meditation can improve concentration.

words.definition: A thing that prevents someone from concentrating on something else.
sentences: Loud noises are a distraction when studying.
He tries to avoid distractions while working.
Social media can be a big distraction.

words.definition: The center of interest or activity.
sentences: Try to focus on your studies.
The camera lens needs to be in focus.
He lost his focus during the game.

words.definition: Motivation that comes from within an individual, rather than from any external or outside rewards.
sentences: His intrinsic motivation to learn was very strong.
Intrinsic motivation leads to greater satisfaction.
She found joy in the work itself, driven by intrinsic motivation.

words.definition: Motivation that comes from outside an individual, such as rewards or avoiding punishment.
sentences: He was driven by extrinsic motivation to earn a good grade.
Extrinsic motivation can be effective for short-term goals.
The prize provided extrinsic motivation for the competition.

words.definition: The object of a person's ambition or effort; an aim or desired result.
sentences: Setting clear goals helps you stay motivated.
Her goal is to finish her degree next year.
He achieved his goal of running a marathon.

words.definition: A hope or ambition of achieving something.
sentences: His aspiration is to become a doctor.
She has high aspirations for her career.
Aspirations drive people to work hard.

words.definition: A thing done successfully, typically by effort, courage, or skill.
sentences: Graduating from college was a great achievement.
His scientific achievements are well-known.
She celebrated her personal achievement.

words.definition: The accomplishment of an aim or purpose.
sentences: Hard work is key to success.
She achieved great success in her career.
Success often comes after many failures.

words.definition: Lack of success.
sentences: Don't be afraid of failure; learn from it.
The project was a complete failure.
Failure can be a stepping stone to success.

words.definition: The belief that abilities can be developed through dedication and hard work.
sentences: Having a growth mindset helps you learn from mistakes.
She encourages her students to adopt a growth mindset.
A growth mindset sees challenges as opportunities.

words.definition: The belief that abilities are fixed traits and cannot be changed.
sentences: A fixed mindset can limit your potential.
He struggled with a fixed mindset about his intelligence.
Overcoming a fixed mindset is important for learning.

words.definition: One's belief in one's ability to succeed in specific situations or accomplish a task.
sentences: High self-efficacy leads to greater persistence.
Building self-efficacy helps in mastering new skills.
His self-efficacy was boosted by his past successes.

words.definition: The realization or fulfillment of one's talents and potentialities, especially considered as a drive or need present in everyone.
sentences: Maslow's hierarchy places self-actualization at the top.
She sought self-actualization through her creative work.
Self-actualization is about becoming your best self.

words.definition: A theory by Abraham Maslow, proposing that people are motivated to fulfill basic needs before moving on to other, more advanced needs.
sentences: Food and shelter are basic needs in Maslow's hierarchy of needs.
The hierarchy of needs explains human motivation.
Understanding the hierarchy of needs can help in helping others.

words.definition: A psychotherapeutic process of learning to identify and dispute irrational or maladaptive thoughts.
sentences: Cognitive restructuring helps change negative thought patterns.
She learned cognitive restructuring in therapy.
Cognitive restructuring is a key technique in CBT.

words.definition: A technique in behavior therapy used to treat anxiety disorders, where the patient is exposed to the feared object or context without any danger, in order to overcome their anxiety.
sentences: Exposure therapy helped him overcome his fear of heights.
She underwent exposure therapy for her phobia.
Exposure therapy is effective for many anxiety disorders.

words.definition: A type of behavioral therapy used to treat phobias and other anxiety disorders, involving gradual exposure to the feared object or situation while the patient is in a relaxed state.
sentences: Systematic desensitization helps reduce fear gradually.
He used systematic desensitization to overcome his fear of flying.
Systematic desensitization combines relaxation with exposure.

words.definition: A type of behavior therapy designed to make a patient give up an undesirable habit by associating it with an unpleasant stimulus.
sentences: Aversion therapy is sometimes used to treat addictions.
The therapy used aversion to reduce smoking.
Aversion therapy can be controversial.

words.definition: A system of behavior modification based on the systematic reinforcement of target behavior.
sentences: The classroom used a token economy to encourage good behavior.
A token economy rewards desired actions.
The token economy helped improve student participation.

words.definition: A theory that states that people learn from one another, via observation, imitation, and modeling.
sentences: Bandura's social learning theory is very influential.
Social learning theory explains how we learn from others.
Observational learning is a key part of social learning theory.

words.definition: A social psychological phenomenon in which individuals are less likely to offer help to a victim when other people are present.
sentences: The bystander effect can prevent people from helping in emergencies.
Understanding the bystander effect can encourage intervention.
The bystander effect highlights group influence.

words.definition: A phenomenon in which a person is less likely to take responsibility for action or inaction when others are present.
sentences: Diffusion of responsibility contributes to the bystander effect.
When many people are present, diffusion of responsibility can occur.
Diffusion of responsibility makes individuals feel less accountable.

words.definition: A psychological experiment designed to study how individuals conform to group pressure.
sentences: Asch's conformity experiment showed how powerful group pressure can be.
The conformity experiment revealed interesting insights into human behavior.
Conformity experiments highlight social influence.

words.definition: Compliance with the commands of an authority figure.
sentences: Milgram's experiment studied obedience to authority.
Obedience to authority can sometimes lead to harmful actions.
Understanding obedience to authority is important in many fields.

words.definition: The tendency for a group to make decisions that are more extreme than the initial inclination of its members.
sentences: Group polarization can lead to more extreme opinions.
Discussions within a group can cause group polarization.
Group polarization is a common phenomenon in social media.

words.definition: The phenomenon of a person exerting less effort to achieve a goal when they work in a group than when they work alone.
sentences: Social loafing can occur in large group projects.
To prevent social loafing, make individual contributions clear.
Social loafing is a challenge in team settings.

words.definition: The loss of self-awareness and self-restraint occurring in group situations that foster arousal and anonymity.
sentences: Crowds can lead to deindividuation.
Deindividuation can sometimes result in impulsive behavior.
Anonymity can contribute to deindividuation.

words.definition: The very front part of the brain, involved in planning, decision-making, and personality.
sentences: The prefrontal cortex is important for rational thought.
Damage to the prefrontal cortex can affect decision-making.
The prefrontal cortex develops throughout adolescence.

words.definition: A part of the brain involved in processing emotions, especially fear.
sentences: The amygdala plays a key role in our fear response.
Research shows the amygdala is active during emotional events.
The amygdala helps us recognize threats.

words.definition: A part of the brain involved in memory formation.
sentences: The hippocampus is crucial for creating new memories.
Damage to the hippocampus can lead to memory loss.
The hippocampus helps us remember events and facts.

words.definition: A chemical substance that transmits nerve impulses across a synapse.
sentences: Dopamine is a neurotransmitter involved in pleasure.
Neurotransmitters carry messages in the brain.
Imbalances in neurotransmitters can affect mood.

words.definition: A neurotransmitter that plays a role in pleasure, motivation, and reward.
sentences: Dopamine is often called the 'feel-good' chemical.
Activities that bring joy release dopamine in the brain.
Dopamine affects our motivation to seek rewards.

words.definition: A neurotransmitter that plays a role in mood, sleep, and appetite.
sentences: Serotonin levels can affect feelings of happiness.
Some medications work by affecting serotonin levels.
Serotonin contributes to overall well-being.

words.definition: A hormone released in response to stress.
sentences: Cortisol is known as the 'stress hormone'.
High cortisol levels can affect health.
The body releases cortisol when under pressure.

words.definition: A hormone released in response to stress or excitement, preparing the body for 'fight or flight'.
sentences: Adrenaline rushed through his body during the roller coaster ride.
The sudden danger caused an adrenaline surge.
Adrenaline helps us react quickly in emergencies.

words.definition: A physiological reaction that occurs in response to a perceived harmful event, attack, or threat to survival.
sentences: The loud noise triggered his fight or flight response.
The fight or flight response prepares the body for danger.
Understanding the fight or flight response can help manage anxiety.

words.definition: A psychotherapeutic process of learning to identify and dispute irrational or maladaptive thoughts.
sentences: Cognitive restructuring helps change negative thought patterns.
She learned cognitive restructuring in therapy.
Cognitive restructuring is a key technique in CBT.

words.definition: A mental structure of preconceived ideas, a framework representing some aspect of the world, or a system of organizing and perceiving new information.
sentences: Our past experiences create mental schemas.
He had a schema for how a typical day should go.
Schemas help us make sense of new information.

words.definition: The process of taking in and fully understanding information or ideas.
sentences: Children use assimilation to fit new information into existing schemas.
The assimilation of new knowledge takes time.
Cultural assimilation can be a complex process.

words.definition: The process by which existing mental structures and behaviors are modified to adapt to new experiences.
sentences: When new information doesn't fit, we use accommodation to change our schemas.
Accommodation is important for cognitive growth.
He made an accommodation to his schedule for the meeting.

words.definition: The part of short-term memory that is concerned with immediate conscious perceptual and linguistic processing.
sentences: Working memory helps us hold information in mind temporarily.
She has excellent working memory for numbers.
Working memory is crucial for problem-solving.

words.definition: Memory that can hold an unlimited amount of information indefinitely.
sentences: Our childhood memories are stored in long-term memory.
Long-term memory allows us to recall past events.
He has a strong long-term memory for facts.

words.definition: Memory that holds a small amount of information for a short period.
sentences: I can only hold a few numbers in my short-term memory.
Short-term memory is like a temporary notepad for the brain.
She tried to remember the phone number using her short-term memory.

words.definition: A partial or total loss of memory.
sentences: After the accident, he suffered from amnesia.
Amnesia can be temporary or permanent.
The movie character had amnesia and couldn't remember his past.

words.definition: An extreme or irrational fear of or aversion to something.
sentences: She has a phobia of spiders.
Acrophobia is the phobia of heights.
Therapy can help overcome a phobia.

words.definition: An anxiety disorder characterized by intrusive thoughts (obsessions) that produce anxiety, and repetitive behaviors (compulsions) aimed at reducing that anxiety.
sentences: OCD can make daily life challenging.
He seeks treatment for his OCD.
OCD involves unwanted thoughts and repetitive actions.

words.definition: A mental health condition triggered by experiencing or seeing a terrifying event.
sentences: PTSD can affect soldiers returning from war.
She received therapy for PTSD.
PTSD symptoms can include flashbacks and nightmares.

words.definition: A long-term mental disorder of a type involving a breakdown in the relation between thought, emotion, and behavior, leading to faulty perception, inappropriate actions and feelings, withdrawal from reality and personal relationships into fantasy and delusion, and a sense of mental fragmentation.
sentences: Schizophrenia is a complex mental illness.
Treatment for schizophrenia often involves medication and therapy.
Schizophrenia affects how a person thinks and feels.

words.definition: A mental disorder characterized by periods of elevated mood (mania or hypomania) and periods of depression.
sentences: Bipolar disorder involves extreme mood swings.
Support and treatment can help manage bipolar disorder.
Living with bipolar disorder requires careful management.

words.definition: An eating disorder characterized by an abnormally low body weight, an intense fear of gaining weight, and a distorted perception of weight.
sentences: Anorexia nervosa is a serious eating disorder.
Treatment for anorexia nervosa involves medical and psychological support.
Anorexia nervosa can have severe health consequences.

words.definition: An eating disorder characterized by binge eating followed by purging.
sentences: Bulimia nervosa involves a cycle of binging and purging.
She sought help for bulimia nervosa.
Bulimia nervosa can damage physical health.

words.definition: The fact or condition of being addicted to a particular substance, thing, or activity.
sentences: Drug addiction is a serious problem.
He sought treatment for his gaming addiction.
Addiction can affect a person's life greatly.

words.definition: The action of restoring someone to health or normal life through training and therapy after imprisonment, addiction, or illness.
sentences: He went to a rehabilitation center for his addiction.
Rehabilitation helps people recover and rebuild their lives.
The program focuses on physical and mental rehabilitation.

words.definition: A return to a normal state of health, mind, or strength.
sentences: Her recovery from illness was slow but steady.
He is in recovery from addiction.
Recovery is a journey, not a destination.

words.definition: The relationship between a therapist and client, characterized by trust, respect, and collaboration.
sentences: A strong therapeutic alliance is crucial for effective therapy.
The therapeutic alliance helps the client feel safe.
Building a good therapeutic alliance takes time.

words.definition: A person trained to give guidance on personal, social, or psychological problems.
sentences: She talked to a school counsellor about her worries.
The counsellor helped him make a difficult decision.
Counsellors provide support and advice.

words.definition: The treatment of mental disorder by psychological rather than medical means.
sentences: Psychotherapy involves talking to a trained professional.
She found psychotherapy very helpful for her depression.
Various types of psychotherapy are available.

words.definition: The identification of the nature of an illness or other problem by examination of the symptoms.
sentences: The doctor gave him a diagnosis of the flu.
A mental health professional can provide a diagnosis.
Early diagnosis can lead to better outcomes.

words.definition: A forecast of the likely course of a disease or ailment.
sentences: The prognosis for his recovery is good.
The doctor explained the prognosis to the family.
A positive prognosis gives hope.

words.definition: A physical or mental feature that is regarded as indicating a condition of disease, particularly a disease that is itself a symptom of another condition.
sentences: Fever is a symptom of many illnesses.
She described her symptoms to the doctor.
Anxiety can have many physical symptoms.

words.definition: A group of symptoms that consistently occur together, or a condition characterized by a set of associated symptoms.
sentences: Down syndrome is a genetic condition.
The patient presented with a rare syndrome.
The doctor recognized the syndrome from the symptoms.

words.definition: A disruption of normal physical or mental functions.
sentences: Anxiety disorder is a common mental health condition.
He was diagnosed with a sleep disorder.
The doctor explained the nature of the disorder.

words.definition: A health condition involving changes in thinking, emotion, or behavior (or a combination of these).
sentences: Mental illness affects many people worldwide.
Seeking help for mental illness is a sign of strength.
Mental illness can be treated with therapy and medication.

words.definition: A mark of disgrace associated with a particular circumstance, quality, or person.
sentences: There is still a stigma around mental illness.
Fighting stigma helps people seek help.
The stigma prevented him from talking about his problems.

words.definition: An unfair and unreasonable opinion or feeling, especially when formed without enough thought or knowledge.
sentences: Social prejudice can lead to discrimination.
She fought against prejudice in her community.
Prejudice often comes from lack of understanding.

words.definition: The practice of treating one person or group differently from another in an unfair way.
sentences: Racial discrimination is a serious issue.
They worked to end discrimination in housing.
Discrimination can cause great harm.

words.definition: The comfort, assistance, and information that people receive from others.
sentences: Having strong social support is important for mental health.
She received a lot of social support during her difficult time.
Social support networks can help reduce stress.

words.definition: Influence from members of one's peer group.
sentences: Teenagers often experience peer pressure.
Peer pressure can be positive or negative.
He resisted peer pressure to try drugs.

words.definition: Adjusting one's behavior or thinking to coincide with a group standard.
sentences: Social conformity can lead people to follow the crowd.
The experiment showed the power of social conformity.
Sometimes social conformity is necessary for harmony.

words.definition: The act of a person helping a victim in an emergency when others are present.
sentences: Bystander intervention can save lives.
Encouraging bystander intervention is important.
The training taught people how to perform bystander intervention.

words.definition: Voluntary behavior intended to benefit another.
sentences: Helping others is a form of prosocial behavior.
Prosocial behavior contributes to a healthy society.
She always encourages prosocial behavior in her students.

words.definition: Behavior that benefits another individual at a cost to oneself.
sentences: Donating blood is an altruistic behavior.
Altruistic behavior is often seen in times of crisis.
His selfless act was truly altruistic behavior.

words.definition: The idea that empathic concern for a person in need produces an altruistic motive for helping.
sentences: The empathy-altruism hypothesis suggests we help others out of genuine care.
According to the empathy-altruism hypothesis, empathy leads to selfless helping.
The study supported the empathy-altruism hypothesis.

words.definition: The effect that the words, actions, or mere presence of other people have on our thoughts, feelings, attitudes, or behavior.
sentences: Advertising is a form of social influence.
Social influence can be powerful in groups.
He was swayed by social influence.

words.definition: The action or process of persuading someone or of being persuaded to do or believe something.
sentences: She used her persuasion skills to convince him.
Advertising relies on persuasion.
Persuasion is a key part of sales.

words.definition: The act or process of complying to a wish or command.
sentences: His compliance with the rules was strict.
The company ensured full compliance with regulations.
Compliance can be influenced by authority.

words.definition: The pressure to change one's behavior or beliefs to match those of a group.
sentences: She felt strong conformity pressure from her peers.
Conformity pressure can lead people to act against their beliefs.
Resisting conformity pressure takes courage.

words.definition: The part played by a person in a particular social setting.
sentences: We all play different social roles in our lives.
Social roles can influence our behavior.
Understanding social roles helps in social interactions.

words.definition: A situation in which a person is expected to play two incompatible roles.
sentences: She experienced role conflict between her job and family duties.
Role conflict can cause stress.
Managing role conflict requires good time management.

words.definition: The theory that people determine their attitudes and preferences by interpreting the meaning of their own behavior.
sentences: Self-perception theory suggests we learn about ourselves by observing our actions.
According to self-perception theory, we infer our feelings from our behavior.
Self-perception theory helps explain attitude change.

words.definition: A theory that describes the process by which individuals explain the causes of behavior and events.
sentences: Attribution theory explores why we explain things the way we do.
He used attribution theory to understand his friend's actions.
Attribution theory helps explain social judgments.

words.definition: The tendency to overestimate the impact of dispositional influences and underestimate the impact of situational influences on other people's behavior.
sentences: The fundamental attribution error leads us to judge others harshly.
Be aware of the fundamental attribution error when evaluating others.
The fundamental attribution error is a common cognitive bias.

words.definition: The tendency to attribute positive events to one's own character or actions, but attribute negative events to external factors.
sentences: The self-serving bias protects our self-esteem.
He showed a self-serving bias by taking credit for success but blaming others for failure.
Self-serving bias is a common human tendency.

words.definition: The process by which individuals evaluate the meaning of environmental events for their well-being.
sentences: Our cognitive appraisal of a situation affects our emotional response.
Stress depends on our cognitive appraisal of a threat.
Cognitive appraisal is a key concept in stress psychology.

words.pronunciation: /…™Ààmo ä É…ôn…ôl Àår…õ…°j äÀàle…™ É…ôn Ààstr√¶t…™d íiz/
words.definition: Methods used to influence which emotions we have, when we have them, and how we experience and express them.
sentences: Deep breathing is one of many emotional regulation strategies.
She learned various emotional regulation strategies in therapy.
Emotional regulation strategies help manage difficult feelings.

words.definition: Techniques and programs used to control levels of stress, especially chronic stress, often for the purpose of improving everyday functioning.
sentences: Exercise and meditation are good for stress management.
She took a course on stress management.
Effective stress management improves overall health.

words.definition: A state of emotional, physical, and mental exhaustion caused by prolonged or excessive stress.
sentences: Long working hours led to burnout.
Burnout can affect anyone in demanding jobs.
Taking breaks can help prevent burnout.

words.definition: The process of developing the ability to recover from or adjust easily to misfortune or change.
sentences: Therapy can help with resilience building.
Resilience building is important for children facing adversity.
Practicing self-care contributes to resilience building.

words.definition: Strategies or programs designed to foster a growth mindset in individuals.
sentences: The school implemented a growth mindset intervention.
Growth mindset interventions can improve academic performance.
The program used a growth mindset intervention to encourage learning.

words.definition: The addition of a reinforcing stimulus following a behavior that makes it more likely that the behavior will occur again in the future.
sentences: Giving praise is a form of positive reinforcement.
Teachers use positive reinforcement to encourage good behavior.
Positive reinforcement is more effective than punishment.

words.definition: The removal of an aversive stimulus following a behavior that makes it more likely that the behavior will occur again in the future.
sentences: Taking away chores for good grades is negative reinforcement.
Negative reinforcement increases a behavior by removing something unpleasant.
Understanding negative reinforcement is key in behavioral psychology.

words.definition: The addition of an aversive stimulus following a behavior that makes it less likely that the behavior will occur again in the future.
sentences: Adding extra chores for misbehavior is positive punishment.
Positive punishment decreases a behavior by adding something unpleasant.
Spanking is an example of positive punishment.

words.definition: The removal of a pleasant stimulus following a behavior that makes it less likely that the behavior will occur again in the future.
sentences: Taking away a toy for bad behavior is negative punishment.
Negative punishment decreases a behavior by removing something pleasant.
Time-outs are a form of negative punishment.

words.definition: A learning process that occurs when two stimuli are repeatedly paired: a response which is at first elicited by the second stimulus is eventually elicited by the first stimulus alone.
sentences: Pavlov's dogs demonstrated classical conditioning.
Classical conditioning explains how we learn associations.
Fear responses can be learned through classical conditioning.

words.definition: A type of learning in which behavior is strengthened if followed by a reinforcer or diminished if followed by a punisher.
sentences: Skinner studied operant conditioning with rats.
Operant conditioning explains how consequences affect behavior.
Rewards and punishments are central to operant conditioning.

words.definition: A theory that states that people learn from one another, via observation, imitation, and modeling.
sentences: Bandura's observational learning theory is very influential.
Observational learning theory explains how we learn by watching others.
Children's behavior is often shaped by observational learning theory.

words.definition: A form of learning where individuals learn new behaviors by observing others.
sentences: Children learn many behaviors through modeling their parents.
Behavioral modeling is a powerful learning tool.
He improved his sports skills through modeling professional athletes.

words.definition: The way in which individuals change their ideas and actions to match those of a group.
sentences: Social influence can lead to fashion trends.
He was affected by social influence in his decision.
Understanding social influence helps in marketing.

words.definition: The way in which individuals change their behavior due to the direct command of an authority figure.
sentences: The experiment showed the power of social influence through obedience.
Social influence can lead to people following orders.
Understanding social influence is important in leadership.

words.definition: The process of guiding oneself or others toward the adoption of an idea, attitude, or action by rational or symbolic means.
sentences: Advertisements use social influence through persuasion.
She is skilled in social influence and persuasion.
Social influence is a key aspect of communication.

words.definition: The extent to which members of a group are bound together, such as by attraction to the group or common goals.
sentences: High group cohesion can improve team performance.
Activities that promote group cohesion are beneficial.
Group cohesion is important for a strong team.

words.definition: An exclusive group of people with a shared interest or identity.
sentences: He felt a strong sense of belonging to his in-group.
In-groups often share common values.
Sometimes people favor their in-group over others.

words.definition: A group that one does not belong to.
sentences: Stereotypes are often applied to out-groups.
She felt like an out-group member in the new club.
Understanding out-groups helps reduce prejudice.

words.definition: A theory that describes how individuals derive their sense of identity from their membership in social groups.
sentences: Social identity theory explains how group membership affects self-esteem.
According to social identity theory, we categorize ourselves and others into groups.
Social identity theory helps understand intergroup relations.

words.definition: A theory that describes the circumstances under which a person will perceive themselves as a member of a group, and the consequences of perceiving themselves as a member of a group.
sentences: Self-categorization theory explains why we identify with certain groups.
The theory of self-categorization is related to social identity.
Self-categorization theory influences group behavior.

words.definition: A shift in one's feelings or beliefs about a person, object, or idea.
sentences: Information can lead to attitude change.
Persuasion aims to achieve attitude change.
Her experiences caused a significant attitude change.

words.definition: The idea that people are motivated to maintain consistency among their beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors.
sentences: Cognitive consistency is a basic human need.
People strive for cognitive consistency to reduce discomfort.
Cognitive consistency helps explain why we avoid conflicting ideas.

words.definition: The study of how people process, store, and apply information about other people and social situations.
sentences: Social cognition helps us understand how we think about others.
She studies social cognition in her psychology class.
Social cognition influences our social interactions.

words.definition: The process by which individuals form judgments and opinions about others.
sentences: First impressions are part of impression formation.
Impression formation happens quickly when meeting new people.
Social cues play a role in impression formation.

words.definition: A situational predicament in which people are or feel themselves to be at risk of conforming to stereotypes about their social group.
sentences: Stereotype threat can affect academic performance.
Understanding stereotype threat helps promote fairness.
Stereotype threat can create anxiety.

words.definition: A social prediction that causes itself to become true due to the actions of the predictor or target.
sentences: Teacher expectations can lead to a social self-fulfilling prophecy.
The belief that a group will fail can become a self-fulfilling prophecy.
Social self-fulfilling prophecies highlight the power of expectations.

words.definition: The way a person typically explains the causes of events, especially positive and negative events.
sentences: His optimistic attributional style helped him cope with setbacks.
A pessimistic attributional style can lead to helplessness.
Attributional style affects how we perceive success and failure.

words.definition: The extent to which people believe they have control over events in their lives.
sentences: Someone with an internal locus of control believes they control their destiny.
An external locus of control means believing outside forces control events.
Locus of control influences motivation and resilience.

words.definition: A condition in which a person suffers from a sense of powerlessness, arising from a traumatic event or persistent failure to succeed.
sentences: Repeated failures can lead to learned helplessness.
Learned helplessness can affect motivation and effort.
Therapy can help overcome learned helplessness.

words.definition: A cognitive strategy by which people avoid effort in the hopes of preventing potential failure from hurting self-esteem.
sentences: He engaged in self-handicapping by not studying for the test.
Self-handicapping can protect ego but hinder success.
Understanding self-handicapping helps explain certain behaviors.

words.definition: Specific methods used to identify, challenge, and change irrational or maladaptive thought patterns.
sentences: Identifying automatic thoughts is one of the cognitive restructuring techniques.
She learned several cognitive restructuring techniques in therapy.
Cognitive restructuring techniques help manage negative thinking.

words.definition: A behavioral therapy that involves increasing engagement in positive and rewarding activities to improve mood and reduce avoidance.
sentences: Behavioral activation is often used to treat depression.
She started a new hobby as part of her behavioral activation plan.
Behavioral activation focuses on increasing enjoyable activities.

words.definition: The stages involved in gradually exposing a person to a feared object or situation while they are relaxed.
sentences: The therapist guided him through the systematic desensitization steps.
The systematic desensitization steps involve creating a fear hierarchy.
Following the systematic desensitization steps carefully is important.

words.definition: Methods used to reduce tension and anxiety, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation.
sentences: Deep breathing is a simple relaxation technique.
She uses various relaxation techniques before bed.
Learning relaxation techniques can improve stress management.

words.definition: A relaxation technique that involves focusing on mental images to promote relaxation or reduce pain.
sentences: Guided imagery can help reduce anxiety before surgery.
She used guided imagery to calm herself.
Guided imagery involves creating peaceful mental pictures.

words.definition: A technique that trains people to improve their health by using signals from their own bodies.
sentences: Biofeedback can help manage chronic pain.
He learned to control his heart rate through biofeedback.
Biofeedback uses sensors to provide real-time information about body functions.

words.definition: The induction of a state of consciousness in which a person loses the power of voluntary action and is highly responsive to suggestion or direction.
sentences: Hypnosis is sometimes used in therapy to help with phobias.
He underwent hypnosis to quit smoking.
Hypnosis can help access the subconscious mind.

words.definition: A technique used in psychotherapy to interpret the content of dreams.
sentences: Freud used dream analysis in his psychoanalytic therapy.
Dream analysis can reveal unconscious thoughts.
She discussed her dreams during dream analysis sessions.

words.definition: A method of exploring the unconscious in which the person relaxes and says whatever comes to mind, no matter how trivial or embarrassing.
sentences: Free association is a technique used in psychodynamic therapy.
During free association, she spoke about her childhood memories.
Free association helps uncover hidden thoughts.

words.definition: The redirection of feelings and desires, especially those unconsciously retained from childhood, toward a new object.
sentences: Transference can occur in therapy, where feelings for others are directed at the therapist.
Understanding transference is important for therapists.
Transference can reveal past relationship patterns.

words.definition: The emotional reaction of the analyst to the subject's transference.
sentences: Therapists must be aware of their own countertransference.
Countertransference can affect the therapeutic relationship.
Supervision helps therapists manage countertransference.

words.definition: In psychoanalysis, the blocking from consciousness of anxiety-laden material.
sentences: The patient showed resistance to discussing certain topics.
Resistance in therapy can indicate important underlying issues.
Overcoming resistance is a goal in psychotherapy.

words.definition: A type of psychotherapy that helps clients understand how their past influences their present behavior.
sentences: Psychodynamic therapy is a form of insight therapy.
Insight therapy aims to increase self-awareness.
He gained valuable insights from insight therapy.

words.definition: A humanistic therapy, developed by Carl Rogers, in which the therapist uses techniques such as active listening within a genuine, accepting, empathic environment to facilitate clients' growth.
sentences: Client-centered therapy focuses on the individual's potential.
The therapist showed unconditional positive regard in client-centered therapy.
Client-centered therapy empowers the client.

words.definition: A concept in client-centered therapy, where the therapist accepts and supports the client regardless of what they say or do.
sentences: Unconditional positive regard helps clients feel accepted.
The therapist offered unconditional positive regard.
Unconditional positive regard is a core principle of humanistic therapy.

words.definition: A communication technique used in counseling, training, and conflict resolution, which requires the listener to fully concentrate, understand, respond and then remember what is being said.
sentences: Active listening is crucial for effective communication.
She practiced active listening in her conversations.
Active listening involves paying full attention.

words.definition: The ability to accurately understand the client's feelings and experiences.
sentences: Therapists strive for empathic understanding of their clients.
Empathic understanding builds trust in relationships.
She showed great empathic understanding towards her friend.

words.definition: The quality of being authentic or real.
sentences: Genuineness in therapy helps build a strong bond.
She appreciated his genuineness and honesty.
Genuineness is an important trait for a therapist.

words.definition: The process of revealing personal information about oneself to another person.
sentences: Appropriate self-disclosure can strengthen relationships.
The therapist used limited self-disclosure.
Self-disclosure helps build trust.

words.definition: The process of testing and evaluating a person's psychological state and abilities.
sentences: Psychological assessment helps diagnose mental health conditions.
She underwent a psychological assessment for her anxiety.
Psychological assessment involves various tests and interviews.

words.definition: A test designed to measure a person's intellectual ability.
sentences: He took an intelligence test in school.
Intelligence tests are used in some psychological assessments.
The intelligence test measured different cognitive abilities.

words.definition: A test designed to measure various aspects of a person's personality.
sentences: She took an online personality test for fun.
Personality tests can provide insights into your traits.
Some companies use personality tests in hiring.

words.definition: A personality test designed to let a person respond to ambiguous stimuli, presumably revealing hidden emotions and internal conflicts.
sentences: The Rorschach inkblot test is a projective test.
Projective tests are used by some psychologists.
Projective tests aim to uncover unconscious thoughts.

words.definition: A personality test that uses a limited or forced-choice format and is scored objectively.
sentences: The MMPI is a well-known objective test.
Objective tests are often used in research.
Objective tests provide standardized scores.

words.definition: The extent to which a test measures what it claims to measure.
sentences: The test's validity was questioned.
High validity means the test accurately measures the concept.
Researchers ensure the validity of their measurements.

words.definition: The consistency of a measure or test.
sentences: The test showed high reliability over time.
Reliability means you get consistent results.
Researchers strive for both validity and reliability.

words.definition: The process of establishing uniform procedures for administering and scoring a test.
sentences: Test standardization ensures fair comparison of results.
Standardization is important for psychological assessments.
The new procedure requires careful standardization.

words.definition: Average scores or patterns of behavior for a particular group, used for comparison.
sentences: Test scores are compared to established norms.
Developmental norms indicate typical milestones for children.
Social norms guide acceptable behavior.

words.definition: The likelihood that a result or relationship is caused by something other than mere random chance.
sentences: The research findings showed statistical significance.
Statistical significance helps determine if results are meaningful.
Scientists look for statistical significance in their data.

words.definition: A mutual relationship or connection between two or more things.
sentences: There is a correlation between exercise and good health.
Correlation does not imply causation.
The study found a strong correlation between the two variables.

words.definition: The action of causing something; the relationship between cause and effect.
sentences: The study aimed to prove causation, not just correlation.
Establishing causation is difficult in research.
Smoking is a direct causation of lung cancer.

words.definition: A factor or condition that can be changed or measured.
sentences: In an experiment, you test how one variable affects another.
Age is a common variable in psychological studies.
Researchers control for different variables.

words.definition: The variable that is changed or controlled in a scientific experiment to test the effects on the dependent variable.
sentences: The independent variable was the amount of study time.
Researchers manipulate the independent variable.
The independent variable is the cause in an experiment.

words.definition: The variable being measured or tested in a scientific experiment.
sentences: The dependent variable was the test score.
The dependent variable changes in response to the independent variable.
Researchers measure the dependent variable.

words.definition: In an experiment, the group that does not receive the treatment, used for comparison.
sentences: The control group received a placebo.
Comparing the experimental group to the control group is important.
The control group helps ensure accurate results.

words.definition: In an experiment, the group that receives the treatment being tested.
sentences: The experimental group received the new medication.
